purpose.p: The Person organization application module supports the requirement to identify an organization and, optionally, a person within it.

inscope.li: the specification of a data structure to identify an organization;
the specification of a data structure to identify a person;
the specification of a data structure to relate a person to an organization;
the specification of a data structure to represent an address;

outscope.li: all concepts not involved in the specification of addresses, organization identification or the identification of people in organizations.

uof.name: Person_Organization
uof.description: The Person_Organization UoF specifies the definitional information for the concept of an organization and an optional person.

aa.refpath: person_and_organization (person_and_organization.the_person -> person<- personal_address.people personal_address) (person_and_organization.the_organization -> organization <- organizational_address.organizations organizational_address)

If the intended domain for the data is large, the reader is referred to ISO/IEC 8824-1 which can provide some guidance on creating unique identifiers. A unique string obtained under ISO/IEC 8824-1 can be used as or prefixed to the identifier. For example, if the organization typically used an identifier of '93699' and the unique string were 'USA', the actual value of the 'person_organization:mim:person_organization_mim:organization:id'>organization id would be 'USA,93699'.
A reference to a person within an organization is established through person_and_organization.

It is typically important that the organization identifier be unique. ISO 10303 provides no direct guidance on how to establish this uniqueness. If the intended domain for the data is large, the reader is referred to ISO/IEC 8824-1 which can provide some guidance on creating unique identifiers. A unique string obtained under ISO/IEC 8824-1 can be used as or prefixed to the organization identifier. It is also typically important that the person identifier be unique within the organization. A method for attempting to assure uniqueness of person identifiers is to utilize the person's Internet electronic mail address for the person identifier. This technique removes any conerns about using a "badge number" or "employee serial number". It allows provides a convenient encoding of computer system user identification information as the user ID can be decoded from the Internet electronic mail address.

usage_guide.p: All pre-processors should provide a unique organization id to eliminate ambiguities where organizations may have the same names.
All post-processors should make use of any provided information in the id attribute to eliminate ambiguities where organizations may have the same name.
